ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is research for credit so the knowledge and skills you develop are directly pertinent to the lab you work in.
basic laboratory techniques, how to write a research paper/proposal, working collaboratively with lab members & PI
Got to do a lot of research in my lab!
Experimental and quantitative research methods (as applicable to my research), how to communicate my research findings through both a written report and an oral presentation
How to write better scientific papers and conduct research a little more independently than I had done in the past.
This course was useful since I got a lot of time to devote to research during the semester.

As an independent study course it is really what you make of it! It will give you a greater understanding on experimental design and follow through as well as allowing you to have time to go into the lab as it gives you another credit.
Opportunity to conduct research and gain practical knowledge about biochemistry and biophysics

This is a great course for immersing yourself into a research experience. I learned to be quite a bit more independent in my thinking in conducting research and reduced the fear of making contributions in novel thought.
I learned how to become a better researcher and address problems in my work.
Learned how to select and develop a research project and form testable hypotheses. The research proposal and final project writing submissions were a main emphasis.
I learned a lot of laboratory skills, including not only the skills within the lab itself but also research and writing skills.
I learned biology research skills.
developed foundational lab skills by working in Damon Clark's lab

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Not really any strenghts/weaknesses. Make sure you work in a lab that you enjoy the topic and have the ability to think independently.
Hard to evaluate this course since it mostly takes place within your lab, but it was all around pretty good! Number of assignments and grading is reasonable.

Strengths: I personally had an amazing experience with this course because I was very interested in my research. I had a ton of advising and guidance both from my PI and my graduate student mentor, which was super helpful. I also had a very clear plan for when/how to conduct my research which I think really helped in this process. 
Weaknesses: Not much! I think that this course is terrific for anyone who has a clear research interest!
A strength is that it was really flexible and a weakness was that the professor didn't communicate with us that much, but I guess that's because we mainly corresponded with our individual PIs.
The course was useful to help students budget time towards research during the semester.

My only recommendation would be to provide a more thorough framework of the expected assignments earlier in the semester as well as a rubric for grading to assist the mentors when evaluating at the end of the term.
The course is structured well for what it is. It fully allows the student to focus mainly on the work in the lab while making sure there is an assignment to ensure that research is being conducted.
Strengths: I think this course would benefit from weekly check-ins rather than an all-encompassing end-of-semester report and presentation.
Normalize not working 20+ hours for no pay. I understand its for credit, but JESUS a small stipend provided by the department wouldnt hurt, dude.
The strength of the course is being able to work in our lab. It could be improved by offering more feedback throughout the course, especially specific feedback on our scientific writing.

The strength is that the research is completely guided by the student and the PI. The weakness is that there is no way for the student to know how they are doing until their grade comes out, since so much of the grade is based on two assignments.

Strengths: flexibility with PI
Weaknesses: the non-PI professor of this course was very specific about writing our proposal and paper to the extent that I was unsure why they were more particular about my research than the PI himself

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are an MB&B major, I would highly recommend doing research for credit (and using it to waive the 251L course). You can do independent work that can help you think like a scientist!
yes! if you are doing research, you might as well take this course & learn how to write a proposal + paper + make a presentation + get great feedback from your labmates on these essential skills.
Yes, if you're planning on doing research anyway!

Yes! I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, but only if the student has a very clear research interest and plan. Truthfully, I think this course is better suited to students who have already had some preliminary experiences working in a research lab. Having guidance from your lab members is very important in this process, and this is best achieved if you already have some sort of prior experience in a given lab.
Yes, if you want a chance to do research in a lab and get credit for it.
I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in doing research during the semester.
Yes, for those looking to conduct research during the school year. The 10 hour a week level is not hard to meet if not slightly low in terms of getting significant data in some fields of research.

I would say: it depends. I spent way more than 10 hrs in lab/week, because that's what felt necessary to make meaningful progress in my project. Even then, I didn't progress as much as I would've hoped. I guess that gives you a general sense what actual science is like, but still found it a bit hard to manage on top of an otherwise rigorous course schedule. That said, I learned a ton, and it's pretty cool to apply the knowledge from this major in a meaningful way as an undergrad.

Yes. If you have enjoyed research from a previous experience and would really appreciate having the structure and challenge of creating a final research paper and talk, this course will be a fulfilling experience overall.
I think its an incredible formative experience, so yes.
I would recommend this course, especially if you are interested in focusing on an independent project for the semester.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is doing research anyway during the semester, its basically a free credit.
I would recommend to any student interested in research.
Yes, if you would like to pursue research during your undergrad I would definitely recommend it
